clinical_study.brief_title: The Effect of Acupotome in Treating Ankylosing Spondylitis

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to evaluate the efficiency and safety of Acupotome in Treating Ankylosing Spondylitis.

primary_outcome.measure: Changes from baseline on McGill Pain Questionnaire (MPQ) at 48 weeks
primary_outcome.description: This wellvalidated questionnaire assesses pain on several dimensions including sensory pain, affective pain, and evaluative pain.

primary_outcome.measure: Changes from baseline on Visual Analog Scale at 48 weeks
primary_outcome.description: This rating scale involved the selection of a point along a 10-cm line, which described pain intensity on a continuum from "no painat all" to "pain as bad as it could be." This scale has been found to be an excellent measure of self-reported pain

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Eligible adult (≥18 years of age) patients
- Had a diagnosis of AS for at least 3 months defined as definite by the 1984 modified New York criteria
- Eligible patients also had a Bath Ankylosing Spondylitis Disease Activity Index (BASDAI) of ≥4 (0-10 cm scale)
- A visual analogue scale (VAS) score for total back pain of ≥4 (0-10 cm scale)
Exclusion Criteria:
- Had received prior acupotome therapy
- With complete ankylosis of the spine, defined as the presence of bridging syndesmophytes at all intervertebral levels of the cervical and lumbar spine on lateral view spinal radiographs
